thread.title: Majority of voters approve of Turnbull replacing Abbott as PM: Newspoll
thread.title_full: Majority of voters approve of Turnbull replacing Abbott as PM: Newspoll | afr.com

author: Edmund Tadros
title: Majority of voters approve of Turnbull replacing Abbott as PM: Newspoll
text:
The majority of voters approve of the elevation of Malcolm Turnbull to PM. Daniel Munoz Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Edmund Tadros Interactive - Explore the poll of polls
Almost two-thirds of voters believe the Liberal Party took the right decision to replace Tony Abbott with Malcolm Turnbull as leader, the latest Newspoll has found.
There is majority support for the decision to install Mr Turnbull as leader across the party divide, with 56 per cent of Coalition supporters and 71 per cent of Labor supporters in favour of the move.
The poll, published in Monday's edition of The Australian , also found the Coalition and Labor both on 50 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, while Mr Turnbull's personal approval rating continued to soar.
The deadlocked two-party preferred polling is in contrast with other national polls carried out since the leadership change that have mostly found the government is ahead of the opposition.
A Roy Morgan poll published last week had the Coalition's two-party preferred vote at 55 per cent, while an Essential poll had the Coalition at 52 per cent.
The Coalition, which won the 2013 election under Mr Abbott with a decisive two-party preferred vote of 53.5 per cent, has not seen support like this since the months immediately following that election.
 All two-party preferred figures are based on preference flow at the last election.
The Newspoll found the Coalition's primary polling is now at 43 per cent while Labor's primary polling is at 35 per cent.
Half of voters surveyed are satisfied with Mr Tunrbull's performance, with the remaining half split evenly between those dissatisfied and those uncommitted.
In contrast, only 28 per cent of voters were satisfied with the performance of Opposition Leader Bill Shorten while more than half, 53 per cent, were dissatisfied. Almost one-fifith, 19 per cent, were uncommitted in their view of Mr Shorten.
The majority of voters, 57 per cent, thought Mr Turnbull a better PM than Mr Shorten.
The survey is based on 1631 interviews carried out between Thursday and Sunday and has a margin of error of 3 per cent.
